title: 114_s2617
content: The Act may be cited as the "MANIFEST for Human Spaceflight Act of 2016" and reaffirms policy and findings. The "MANIFEST for Human Spaceflight Act of 2016" reaffirms Congress's goal for NASA to expand human presence beyond low-Earth orbit with international partners. Congress acknowledges findings from the National Academy of Sciences regarding human space flight goals and core capabilities. The Committee on Human Spaceflight, comprised of leaders from various sectors, concluded that human space exploration has multiple rationales including economic benefits, national security, and scientific discovery. They affirmed Mars as the long-term goal and recommended NASA define sustainable steps to achieve it. The Committee on Human Spaceflight identified multiple rationales for human space exploration, including economic benefits, national security, and scientific discovery. They affirmed Mars as the long-term goal and recommended NASA define sustainable steps to achieve it. SEC. 3. HUMAN EXPLORATION STRATEGY. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act of 2010 is amended to include human exploration of Mars as a goal, with a strategy involving successive missions in cis-lunar space. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration Authorization Act of 2010 is amended to include human exploration of Mars as a goal, with a strategy involving missions in cis-lunar space that utilize the Space Launch System, Orion crew capsule, and other capabilities. The strategy includes expanding human presence in cis-lunar space for missions to various destinations, collaboration with international partners, private industry, and other Federal agencies. The curr_chunk discusses opportunities for scientific research and technological developments in space, including utilizing the International Space Station (ISS) and exploring mission architectures for missions in cis-lunar space and beyond. It also includes a comparison of different approaches based on factors like cost effectiveness, safety, and international collaboration. The curr_chunk discusses measures for setting standards to ensure crew health and safety in space, including radiation exposure limits and necessary countermeasures. The curr_chunk outlines crew health and safety measures, including radiation exposure limits and necessary countermeasures, training needs, prioritizing missions, and assessing previous recommendations. The curr_chunk discusses the Administrator's incorporation of recommendations into the strategy and the provision of technical information to identify interest from stakeholders. An independent review by the National Academy of Sciences is required to comment on each interim report on the strategy. The Administrator must ensure timely review and comment on interim reports by the National Academy of Sciences to incorporate their recommendations into the final report required by the subsection within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Administrator must submit interim reports to the National Academy of Sciences every five years for independent review, with final reports to Congress incorporating the Academy's responses.
